Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2013
Award.AbstractNarration:
A large-scale, experimental test of how habitat fragmentation affects trophic structure, species niches, and extinction risk

Fundamental properties of populations and communities are affected by habitat loss and fragmentation--pervasive threats to many ecosystems. Because effects of landscape alteration are complex and intertwined, a central goal of landscape ecology is to tease apart the mechanisms through which populations and communities are altered by changes of habitat patches. Manipulative experiments provide a means to this end. The fellow will assess impacts of fragmentation on a diverse community of beetles in a large-scale experiment, the Wog Wog Habitat Fragmentation Experiment in Australia. Specifically the project focuses on determining: 1) How fragmentation affects trophic structure and 2) the niche space of beetle species; 3) Whether a given beetle species? niche space predicts its extinction risk in fragments. The fellow will use beetle carbon and nitrogen stable isotope ratios (ä13C and ä15N) to address these questions. In addition to providing a mechanistic understanding of how fragmentation affects a diverse arthropod community, these results will serve conservation biology by predicting which species are most at risk by fragmentation.

This fellow will be trained in quantitative skills, stable isotope analysis, teaching, and mentoring. The fellow is committed to education and providing research opportunities to undergraduate students, especially those from underrepresented groups, and to being a role model in the classroom, laboratory, and field. The teaching components of this project will include developing course material in collaboration with Science Teaching Fellows in University of Colorado's Science Education Initiative (a STEM initiative) and developing K-12 material in collaboration with undergraduates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Habitat fragmentation can alter the trophic structure of communities and environmental conditions, thus driving changes in biodiversity and ecological processes. A gap in ecology is the understanding of fragmentation and spatial conformation of habitat affects trophic structure and species’ niches. Because trophic structure and dynamics greatly influence ecosystem stability and function, understanding how they are impacted by fragmentation is key to predicting how species will respond to fragmentation.

The Wog Wog habitat fragmentation experiment allows for control of typically confounding extraneous variables at scales relevant to management and with sufficient replication. The combination of the experimental design and long time frame provided an excellent opportunity to better understand the effects of fragmentation on biodiversity and ecological processes.

The postdoctoral fellow used stable isotopes of a generalist predator skink and invertebrates to test predictions from spatial theory on trophic structure and to quantify abiotic changes associated with fragmentation among continuous forest, fragments, and matrix habitats. He predicted that in fragments and the matrix, isotopic niches would shift due to decreases in skink trophic positions (δ15N) from reductions in trophic structure of arthropod food webs and abiotic changes over time (δ13C) relative to continuous forest. Contrary to these predictions, he did not find reductions in trophic structure with fragmentation. In fact, skink δ15N values were higher in the matrix and fragments than matrix. This was likely due to changes in distributions of a detritivorous prey species, a terrestrial amphipod. In addition, δ13C values in the matrix habitat decreased over time since fragmentation due to abiotic changes associated with matrix tree maturation. This work showed how isotopic niches are influenced by fragmentation via shifts in biotic and abiotic processes. The potential for either or both spatial and abiotic effects of fragmentation present a challenge for theory to better predict ecological changes in fragmented landscapes. These findings were disseminated in publications, conference presentations, undergraduate class content, and K-12 outreach.


Objectives for the postdoctoral fellow also included training in teaching, and mentoring. The postdoctoral fellow received formal training through workshops to learn best practices in science teaching. These included active learning strategies. He put these strategies into practice by developing and teaching a module on population ecology in undergraduate introductory biology classes throughout the fellowship tenure. He also shared his research experience with students in the form of short presentations on his background and how he became an ecologist and with a short video on his research in the field. During this module teaching experts observed classes and provided written feedback. The postdoctoral fellow mentored fourteen undergraduate students during this fellowship.
